title: Vaccines, Inactivated, Bacterial: Drug Class, Uses, Side Effects, Drug Names
author: Medical Reviewer Sarfaroj Khan; BHMS; PGD Health Operations
description: Inactivated bacterial vaccines are sterile biologic products that provide acquired immunity against certain bacterial infections. Learn about how they work, usages, side effects, and a list of drugs.
cleaned_text: How do inactivated bacterial vaccines work? Inactivated [bacterial](https://www.rxlist.com/bacterial/definition.htm) [vaccines](https://www.rxlist.com/vaccines/definition.htm) are sterile biologic that provide [acquired immunity](https://www.rxlist.com/acquired_immunity/definition.htm) against certain bacterial infections. Inactivated bacterial vaccines work by stimulating the body's [immune system](https://www.rxlist.com/immune_system/definition.htm) to produce antibodies against specific types of [bacteria](https://www.rxlist.com/bacteria/definition.htm), and protect a person from becoming infected when exposed to these bacteria. Inactivated bacterial vaccines are made from [proteins](https://www.rxlist.com/proteins/definition.htm) or fragments of [disease](https://www.rxlist.com/disease/definition.htm)-causing bacteria grown [in](https://www.rxlist.com/in/definition.htm) [culture](https://www.rxlist.com/culture/definition.htm) and then killed (inactivated) to prevent them from causing disease. Inactivated bacterial vaccines also contain substances that preserve and stabilize the vaccine, and boost [immune response](https://www.rxlist.com/immune_response/definition.htm). The main component of inactivated bacterial vaccines is the bacterial [antigen](https://www.rxlist.com/antigen/definition.htm) against which the [immune](https://www.rxlist.com/immune/definition.htm) system produces antibodies. If exposed to the particular bacterial [infection](https://www.rxlist.com/infection/definition.htm) later in life, the immune system of the vaccinated person identifies the bacteria by the antigen, attacks and kills the bacteria, preventing illness. Some inactivated bacterial vaccines are conjugated with [tetanus](https://www.rxlist.com/tetanus/definition.htm) or [diphtheria](https://www.rxlist.com/diphtheria/definition.htm) bacterial toxoids to improve the immune response. Toxoids are toxins that are chemically altered to eliminate [toxicity](https://www.rxlist.com/toxicity/definition.htm), but can be recognized as bacterial antigens by the immune system. Inactivated bacterial vaccines do not provide as strong or long-lasting [immunity](https://www.rxlist.com/immunity/definition.htm) as weakened live vaccines do, but are effective for people with compromised immunity. Inactivated bacterial vaccines provide immunity against the following bacterial infectious diseases: [Anthrax](https://www.rxlist.com/anthrax/definition.htm), caused by [Bacillus anthracis](https://www.rxlist.com/bacillus_anthracis/definition.htm)bacteria - Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) bacterial infection - Meningococcal disease, caused by [Neisseria](https://www.rxlist.com/neisseria/definition.htm)meningitidis bacteria serogroups A, C, Y and W-135 - Meningococcal disease, caused by Neisseria meningitidis bacteria serogroup B [Pneumonia](https://www.rxlist.com/pneumonia/definition.htm), caused by multiple strains of [Streptococcus pneumoniae](https://www.rxlist.com/streptococcus_pneumoniae_pneumococcus/definition.htm)bacteria - Tetanus, caused by [Clostridium](https://www.rxlist.com/clostridium/definition.htm)tetani bacteria How are inactivated bacterial vaccines used? Inactivated bacterial vaccines may be administered in a series of doses on a prescribed schedule as [intramuscular](https://www.rxlist.com/intramuscular_im/definition.htm) (IM) injections into the [muscle](https://www.rxlist.com/muscle/definition.htm) or [subcutaneous](https://www.rxlist.com/subcutaneous/definition.htm) (SC) injections into the [tissue](https://www.rxlist.com/tissue/definition.htm) under the [skin](https://www.rxlist.com/skin/definition.htm). Inactivated bacterial vaccines are approved by the [FDA](https://www.rxlist.com/fda/definition.htm) for use in: Children and adolescents - Meningococcal primary and booster immunization for healthy individuals - Meningococcal immunization for individuals at high-risk conditions includes: - Routine pneumococcal [vaccination](https://www.rxlist.com/vaccination/definition.htm)for healthy individuals - Pneumococcal vaccination for individuals at risk with: - Compromised/suppressed immunity [Cerebrospinal fluid](https://www.rxlist.com/cerebrospinal_fluid/definition.htm)leak [Cochlear implant](https://www.rxlist.com/cochlear_implant/definition.htm) - Primary and booster tetanus vaccination Adults - Pre-exposure [prophylaxis](https://www.rxlist.com/prophylaxis/definition.htm)for anthrax in people at high risk [Post-exposure prophylaxis](https://www.rxlist.com/post-exposure_prophylaxis/definition.htm)for anthrax - Haemophilus influenzae type B immunization in individuals who have: - Asplenia - Complement deficiency - Undergone [hematopoietic](https://www.rxlist.com/hematopoietic/definition.htm)( [stem [transplant](https://www.rxlist.com/transplant/definition.htm) - Primary and booster meningococcal immunization - Meningococcal immunization for individuals at high-risk conditions that include: - Asplenia - Complement deficiency - Use of complement inhibiting medications - HIV infection - Microbiologists who are routinely exposed to Neisseria meningitidis - Community outbreak - Travel to endemic/epidemic areas - Pneumococcal vaccination for individuals with: - Primary and booster tetanus vaccination What are side effects of inactivated bacterial vaccines? Side effects of inactivated bacterial vaccines may include the following: - Injection site reactions include: [Erythema](https://www.rxlist.com/erythema/definition.htm)(redness) - Swelling [Pain](https://www.rxlist.com/pain/definition.htm)and soreness - Tenderness and warmth Abnormally prolonged crying - Decreased appetite [Anorexia](https://www.rxlist.com/anorexia/definition.htm)(appetite loss) [Nausea](https://www.rxlist.com/nausea/definition.htm) - Vomiting [Diarrhea](https://www.rxlist.com/diarrhea/definition.htm) - Limitation of [arm](https://www.rxlist.com/arm/definition.htm)motion of [nose](https://www.rxlist.com/nose/definition.htm)and - Oropharyngeal pain such as: [Erythema multiforme](https://www.rxlist.com/erythema_multiforme/definition.htm)( [round](https://www.rxlist.com/round/definition.htm)lesions like a bullseye) [Angioedema](https://www.rxlist.com/angioedema/definition.htm)(swelling in the tissue under the skin or [mucous](https://www.rxlist.com/mucous/definition.htm)membranes) - Tonic [convulsion](https://www.rxlist.com/convulsion/definition.htm) - movement) [Ptosis](https://www.rxlist.com/ptosis/definition.htm)(droopy of muscle tissue) Information contained herein is not intended to cover all possible side effects, precautions, warnings, drug interactions, allergic reactions, or adverse effects. Check with your [doctor](https://www.rxlist.com/doctor/definition.htm) or [pharmacist](https://www.rxlist.com/pharmacist/definition.htm) to make sure these drugs do not cause any harm when you take them along with other medicines. Never stop taking your [medication](https://www.rxlist.com/medication/definition.htm) and never change your dose or frequency without consulting your doctor.
